newsitem.title: UK: Yorks Water to continue improving performance.
newsitem.headline: Yorks Water to continue improving performance.

text.p: British water and sewerage company Yorkshire Water Plc said on Friday that it would continue to improve performance to achieve "the best possible outcome for both customers and shareholders" at its next price review in 1999.

Yorkshire said annual pretax profits rose to 215.8 million pounds ($353.4 million) from 162.2 million previously and paid out a total dividend of 18.5 pence per share, which was up 19.4 percent from a previous adjusted 15.5 pence to take account of a capital restructuring.
"The last year has been one of focus," the company said in a statement, adding that customers were its priority, with heavy investment to improve service.

It said that even if the conditions of 1995 were repeated, when a very dry summer in Yorkshire's area almost forced cuts in essential domestic supplies, "water restrictions should not prove to be necessary this summer."
The company said it had reduced leakage and introduced a free service to mend leaks on customers' pipes and those of businesses and Yorkshire said it was "determined" to reduce leakage further.

Britain's new Labour government has said it will set mandatory targets for cutting leaks as part of a 10-point crisis plan aimed at dealing with the country's worst drought in 200 years, and it also plans a one-off tax on the "excess profits" of privatised utilities which could include Yorkshire.
